results.title: The Bill. Gentleman Jim
results.brief_description: ‘The Bill’ is a UK police drama that explores both criminals and police. ‘Gentleman Jim’ contains three episodes of ‘The Bill’ featuring Jim Carver (Mark Wingett). Wingett wrote the first of these three episodes. ‘Saved’ (1995, produced by Pat Sandys, directed by Jeremy Silberston): back in his drinking days Jim Carver is loosing his faith in the police force and in particular, his usefulness. To combat his so called “desk fatigue”, he is called to help in a raid on a crack house. Jim helps a prostitute - restoring his sense of worth. ‘True to life player’ (1997, produced by Chris Clough, directed by Simon Meyers): focuses on a once local boy’s rise to fame as a footballer who is accused of rape by an underage girl. Is she lying, or is he? As the story unfolds the audience is in doubt while Jim Carver plays his role as investigating officer. ‘Gentleman Jim’ (1997, produced by Pat Sandys, directed by Mike Vardy): Jim is teamed up with an overly enthusiastic uniformed officer on secondment in C.I.D. Her drive and initiative conflicts with the slightly stale and crabby Jim. Experience wins over enthusiasm and Jim reveals himself as the decent man and policeman that he is.

results.title: The Bill. A bunch of fives
results.brief_description: ‘The Bill’ is a UK police drama that explores both criminals and police. ‘A Bunch of fives’ (1997, produced by Michael Simpson, directed by Chris Lovett): one of the Sunhill officers is found beaten unconscious in an alley at the back of a Chinese restaurant. This causes a zero tolerance stance from the rest of the officers while they try to find the culprit. Does a policeman need to be beaten before the police do any work at Sunhill? ‘Death of a nobody’ (1996, produced by Chris Clough, directed by Simon Meyers): a man is found murdered. A mystery unfolds when he’s identified as a choir singing, onion growing taxi driver. Have they killed the wrong man? A polaroid, an answering machine and a suspicious private investigator are the only clues in this mysterious one hour episode.

results.title: The Bike
results.brief_description: An open-ended film in which two boys use another boy’s bike without permission and break it. Raises quiestions about property and responsibility for one’s actions. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Big stride
results.creator_credit: John Dobson, Peter Bale and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Tells of the construction of Britain’s second-longest suspension bridge, across the River Severn, from its earliest beginnings to its opening by Queen Elizabeth in 1966. In terms of scientific advance, economy and beauty it is superlative, and its construction points the way to the bridge across the Humber which will be the biggest in the world.

results.title: The Big red barn
results.creator_credit: Robert Ennis, Joe Hayward, John Churchill and Moreland-Latchford Productions
results.brief_description: Describes the daily life and activities of the domesticated animals of a farm that live together in the big red barn. Encourages creativity in oral and written expression, as the film is narrated in rhyming verse. Based on the story by Margaret Wise Brown. Suitable for lower primary level.

results.title: The Big island [Italian version]
results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The aim of this film is to show an international audience within a limited time span some attractive aspects of Australian life. Representing a brisk and exciting place and creating a mood of a country on the move. Cinematography by Keith Gow and Don McAlpine. Music by George Dreyfus. (Awards: AFI Travel Award 1970)

results.title: The Big fellow
results.creator_credit: Michel Pearce, Kip Porteous and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description: Reconstructs the political career of J.T. Lang, Premier of New South Wales in 1925-1927 and 1930-1932, using contemporary film and stills and the recollections of some of the people most involved. Narrated by Allan Fraser. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The Bif if
results.creator_credit: Vivienne King and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Looks at research being done on the drug Interferon. It is a substance that has been shown to have an effect on some viruses and tumors and scientists are hopeful that it will cure cancer and other life threatening diseases. A cheap synthetic version, if developed, would enable scientists to meet current world demand.

results.title: The Best time of my life
results.brief_description: Women in mid-life share their thoughts and experiences of menopause. This film provides role models who demonstrate that there is life after menopause.

results.title: The Best of Gillies (Captioned)
results.brief_description: The Gillies Team takes on numerous national treasures (including Bob Hawke, Andrew Peacock, Wran the Man and Don Chipp) and even the odd megabuck personality such as Rupert Murdoch in this new compilation video selected from the hilarious Gillies Report series. Highlights include Bob Hawke as the Invisible Man: the Maralinga Commission (or Wise After the Event) re-enacted in the form of a cabaret, with Mr. Justice McLelland chairing the proceedings in sparkling silver lurex; and John Clarke - posing as a sports announcer - introduces us to the magnificent game of Farnarkeling. Featuring: Max Gillies, John Clarke, Patricia Cooke, Tracey Harvey, Don Watson, Geoff Kelso, Wendy Harmer & Phillip Scott. Rated: PG
